items.title: Sport stars call for federal royal commission into antisemitism and Bondi attack

items.summary: SA Police say 72 people were arrested and 10 were reported for offences overnight as the state rang in the new year.

items.title: Australian K-pop idol Danielle dropped from NewJeans and sued for more than $44 million
items.summary: An Australian K-pop idol caught up in a bitter dispute with her former record label is sued for more than $44 million and dropped from her group.

items.title: Amyl and the Sniffers singer Amy Taylor files lawsuit against photographer
items.summary: Punk rock frontwoman of Amyl and the Sniffers Amy Taylor has filed a lawsuit against an American photographer alleging that photos taken for a magazine photo shoot are being sold against her wishes and without her permission.

items.title: Boxer Anthony Joshua discharged from hospital after car crash in Nigeria
items.summary: British former world heavyweight boxing champion Anthony Joshua is discharged from hospital days after a car accident that killed two of his close friends.

items.title: Boy, 15, dies in e-bike crash in Tasmania's north on New Year's Eve
items.summary: A 15-year-old boy has died in an e-bike crash on New Year's Eve, described by Tasmanian police as "tragic" and prompting a call for riders to comply with the law.

items.title: Rescue authorities search for missing man on Coogee Beach

items.title: Australian meat industry warns China's new beef tariff impact will be 'severe'
items.summary: Meat Industry Council says it is "extremely disappointed" as China imposes a tariff on Australian beef imports that could cost $1 billion.

items.title: Pat Cummins, Josh Hazlewood and Tim David named in Australia's T20 World Cup squad despite injuries
items.summary: Pat Cummins, Josh Hazlewood and Tim David are all included in Australia's 15-player squad for next month's men's Twenty20 World Cup in Sri Lanka and India.

items.title: Lorin's father, satirist John Clarke, had a story to tell so she recorded their conversations
items.summary: When Lorin Clarke asked her father, satirist John Clarke, if she could start recording their conversations, she thought it would just be for them. But when he tragically died aged 68, one year after the recordings began, Lorin felt his story belonged to more than just her.

items.title: Permanent commercial demersal fishing ban begins for large part of WA
items.summary: From today, commercial demersal fishing is banned along hundreds of kilometres of the WA coastline in an effort to recover fish species numbers.

items.title: Rare freshwater Bloomfield River cod surviving amid environmental threats
items.summary: The Bloomfield River cod, found in a far north Queensland river catchment, is the world's only tropical freshwater cod, and scientists are working to have it officially protected amid threats from the climate and introduced species.

items.title: The Bloomfield River cod is the world's only tropical freshwater cod

items.title: Three drown, man and teenage boy missing in multiple coastal emergencies off NSW waters
items.summary: A man and two women have died and two people are missing following four separate incidents on Sydney waters over the past 48 hours.

items.title: Police happy with Victorian NYE revellers despite multiple arrests and illegal fireworks injuries
items.summary: Police make 18 arrests and several people are taken to hospital for injuries related to illegal fireworks as Victorians see in the new year.

items.title: Four titan arum 'corpse flowers' to bloom in a week at Cairns Botanic Gardens
items.summary: Renowned for their size and stench, blooming corpse flowers are a rare occurrence. But to have four flowering in a week is "something of a record".

items.title: Handwritten letters among items in the unsealed case file of hanged murderer Jean Lee
items.summary: Jean Lee and her two co-accused were executed for murder in 1950. Handwritten letters from the trio are among items publicly available for the first time since their trial captured the nation's attention.

items.title: Chris Lynn wins Adelaide Strikers' New Year's Eve BBL game against Brisbane Heat
items.summary: Former Brisbane star Chris Lynn clobbers the Adelaide Strikers to an easy victory over the Heat in the New Year's Eve Big Bash League clash.

items.title: Jurassic Park fan fulfils childhood dream of recreating Jeep
items.summary: Zakary Weyer's obsession with Jurassic Park drove him to learn different skills to build a replica of the Jeep that appears in the iconic blockbuster.

items.title: Brisbane Roar coach Michael Valkanis's send-off sparks half-time clash with Central Coast Mariners
items.summary: The fallout from Brisbane Roar's spiteful A-League clash with Central Coast continues, with the Roar "considering all options" after comments from Mariners coach Warren Moon following a send-off for Brisbane coach Michael Valkanis that prompted a half-time confrontation in Gosford.

items.title: High-dose MDMA warning for revellers attending Sydney's Field Day
items.summary: A pill testing trial has been expanded to Sydney's Field Day music festival, but authorities are urging partygoers not to be complacent.

items.title: Around the world people celebrate new year and hope 2026 brings peace
items.summary: Cities around the world have rung in the new year in spectacular style, with fireworks lighting up famous landmarks from the London Eye to Egypt's pyramids.

items.title: Two people charged after police find explosive devices at a property in Bendigo
items.summary: A man and a woman will face court charged with numerous offences, including manufacturing unauthorised explosive devices.

items.title: Double stabbing in popular dining strip in Carlton leaves two men in hospital
items.summary: Two men were taken to hospital with serious injuries after being stabbed in Carlton shortly before midnight.

items.title: What ABC journalists will be closely watching in 2026
items.summary: Disruptions to the world trade system courtesy of Donald Trump and a reshaping of historic alliances as multiple wars drag on have set the stage for a precarious year in global affairs.

items.title: How running helped Darwin entertainer Shalom Kaa overcome substance abuse
items.summary: Shalom Kaa used to think running was something other people did. But after a series of events that left him at his lowest, running became a big part of his recovery following years of substance abuse with crystal methamphetamines.

items.title: Today in History, January 1: Evonne Goolagong wins her first Australian Open title
items.summary: After an extended break and a shower, Goolagong changed tactics in the deciding set to sail to victory over American Chris Evert back in 1974.

items.title: Previously secret cabinet documents reveal Howard government tried to mitigate 'homegrown' terrorist threat
items.summary: From expectations of a trade union backlash against controversial industrial relations reform, to concerns about "homegrown" extremism in Australia, here are what previously unseen cabinet documents tell us about Australian politics in 2005.

items.summary: News from the world of finance and business. Top stories in text, video and audio. Business video news bulletin. Features and analysis.

items.title: Felix Auger-Aliassime hopes for deep Australian Open run after career-best year
items.summary: After his best year on tour, Canadian star Felix Auger-Aliassime is looking to keep his hot streak running in the United Cup and at the Australian Open.

items.title: Man drowns and boy missing after boat capsizes at Palm Beach
items.summary: Police confirmed one man has drowned and a 14-year-old boy is missing after their boat capsized at Palm Beach on Sydney's Northern Beaches, with a search and rescue helicopter continuing to search the area.

items.title: Pet owner's warning as dogs fall ill after beach visit amid algal bloom crisis
items.summary: Within 20 minutes of leaving an Adelaide beach dogs Lucy and Ella began breathing rapidly and fell "terribly sick", prompting their owner to issue a warning.

items.title: Driver in hit and run that killed woman on Darwin's Bagot road remains at large
items.summary: The search for a hit-and-run driver who allegedly struck and killed a 27-year-old Indigenous woman on one of Darwin's busiest main roads continues into its fifth day.

items.title: Sunshine Coast live music venue The Station to shut down as event bookings drop
items.summary: The Sunshine Coast's largest live music venue is shutting down, with the owners stating that they need double the number of bookings to stay afloat.

items.title: Muslim community members sleep in mosques as Islamophobic threats rise after Bondi mass shooting
items.summary: A rise in Islamophobic incidents prompts warnings from Muslim organisations that their communities are at risk of "retribution" and "collective punishment" following the mass shooting.

items.title: Australia's top glassmakers are the focus of the exhibition Glass Chrysalis II
items.summary: The art of glassblowing was popularised in a recent reality TV series, but these Australian artists are forging their own paths in the creative process of sculpting this tricky medium.

items.title: Socceroos striker Martin Boyle in injury blow for Hibernian
items.summary: Martin Boyle, no stranger to the heartache of missing major tournaments with the Socceroos, was taken off after injuring his hamstring for Hibernian in the Scottish Premiership.

items.title: 'White Australia' flyer letterbox drop in Newcastle sparks police investigation
items.summary: NSW Premier Chris Minns said police would "throw the book" at anyone behind flyers distributed to inner-city Newcastle letterboxes.

items.title: Ashes 2025: Alex Hartley responds to criticism for talking about period on BBC commentary
items.summary: Alex Hartley says she was stunned by the reaction to her talking about her period during the BBC's radio commentary of the third Ashes Test.

items.title: Promise of bumper coffee crop in 2026 fuelled by explosion of white flowers
items.summary: Australian coffee growers are hoping for a bumper 2026 season to meet increased demand for homegrown beans following a prolific flowering season.

items.title: Former Australian Test batsman Damien Martyn in an induced coma with meningitis
items.summary: Former Australian Test and limited overs batsman Damien Martyn is in hospital in Queensland in an induced coma after falling ill this week.

items.title: Costumes of Kylie, Rihanna, Lady Gaga, Amy Taylor and more showcased in new DIVA exhibition
items.summary: The exhibition at Melbourne's newest museum, featuring Kylie Minogue's catsuit and Elton John's Louis XIV-inspired 50th birthday outfit, celebrates the power of divas through time.

items.title: Calls for national strategy to tackle apprentice hazing and protect workers’ mental health
items.summary: TV presenter and former builder Barry Du Bois is lobbying Canberra for change.

items.title: Broken Hill gardeners chop down trees in battle with Queensland fruit fly
items.summary: There was no fruit fly to be found in Broken Hill 20 years ago, but now gardeners are facing an uphill battle trying to rid themselves of the pest.

items.title: Photos that captured the stories and people of regional WA in 2025
items.summary: The stunning photos that captured the stories and people of regional WA in 2025.

items.title: AI technology gives swimming pool lifeguards an extra set of eyes this summer
items.summary: An AI system used in 120 public pools across Australia analyses swimmers' movements and sends an alert to a lifeguard's smartwatch if it detects someone in trouble.

items.title: What are the new rules in 2026? Here's what's changing from New Year's Day
items.summary: New Year's Day brings a host of new laws, regulations and guidelines into effect. Here's a quick breakdown of some of the changes.

items.title: Calls for tighter regulations after Woodside knowingly shed plastic into ocean
items.summary: Documents reveal one of Australia's biggest oil and gas companies knowingly shed plastic into the ocean for two months before notifying the offshore regulator.

items.title: Record year for Australian beef exports despite Donald Trump's tariffs
items.summary: When Donald Trump enforced a 10 per cent tariff on Australian beef, there were some concerns it would impact trade. But the opposite happened.

items.title: Flocks of tourists dubbed the 'koala paparazzi' putting animals at risk in Byron Bay
items.summary: Large crowds of tourists gather daily at the bottom of trees home to koalas in Byron Bay, leaving the animals stressed and their habitat trampled.

items.title: Tatiana Schlossberg, granddaughter of John F Kennedy, dies aged 35
items.summary: Tatiana Schlossberg revealed in an essay published in November that she had a rare form of terminal leukaemia.

items.title: ASX ends 'stressful' year with gold and lithium stocks surging despite Trump's trade war threats
items.summary: Several gold, lithium and other mining stocks have seen their share price double, and even triple, in 2025 as Australia's share market has had a much better than expected year despite tariffs, economic uncertainty and Donald Trump's ongoing unpredictability.

items.title: Mechanic shortage driving Queensland businesses to look overseas for qualified workers
items.summary: The automotive repair industry says it is dealing with a major labour and skills shortage, and some mechanics are looking overseas for workers.

items.title: Cameron Corner celebrates New Year's Eve three times in one night, on three state borders
items.summary: It's more than 1,000km from any capital city, but Cameron Corner, at the junction of the NSW, Queensland and South Australian borders, reckons it has one of the best New Year's Eve parties going around because it is a triple celebration over three time zones.

items.title: Robbers steal $52 million from vault of German savings bank
items.summary: According to police, the robbers drilled their way into the underground vault room of the savings bank from a parking garage.

items.title: Denmark becomes first country in world to end letter delivery
items.summary: After 401 years, the Danish postal service has ended letter deliveries as the country fully embraces the digital age.

items.title: What should you do during a violent mass attack?
items.summary: The mass shooting in Bondi and other incidents of mass violence around the world have highlighted that violence can strike anywhere. Here are some expert tips on how to escape, hide, and stay safe.

items.title: Human-operated Tokyo robot venture allows housebound people to work
items.summary: Ory Yoshifuji's Tokyo business employs housebound individuals to operate robots as waitstaff at a cafe and as personal tour guides in the city.

items.title: Sportsbet pressured key watchdog into 'watering down' enforcement announcement
items.summary: Gambling giant Sportsbet pressured the Australian Communications and Media Authority into "watering down" enforcement announcement, the ABC can reveal.

items.title: Crowd-funding business campaigns falter, despite demand for tipple
items.summary: Brewer Richard Jeffares's Victorian company raised about $2.5 million from 993 investors in a matter of days through a method called crowd-sourced funding, also known as equity crowdfunding.

items.title: Kakadu traditional owner says nature has long warned us about rising sea levels
items.summary: In wet season, Jonathan and his family have to drive, boat and drive again if they want to reach town. The remote NT traditional owner says nature has long been warning us about climate change, "but nobody's listening".

items.title: Christmas cruise ends in chaos as Coral Adventurer passengers return home
items.summary: About 80 passengers on the Coral Adventurer are flown home after the cruise ship ran aground on a reef off Papua New Guinea.

items.title: South Korea bans bear bile farming with jail for those who breach the law
items.summary: South Korea is one of the few countries that allow farming to extract bile from bears, for traditional medicine or food believed to promote vitality and stamina.

items.title: Bizzi Lavelle uncovers the hidden history of Blak burlesque in Australia
items.summary: Bizzi Lavelle, a Queer Wakka Wakka and Arrernte writer and burlesque dancer known in the scene as Bizzi Body, is reclaiming the hidden legacy of this art-form one tassel twirl at a time.

items.title: Here's what we know about the Coral Adventurer, the cruise ship that ran aground in PNG
items.summary: The Coral Adventurer was carrying 80 tourists into the remote reaches of Papua New Guinea when it came to an abrupt halt on a reef off the Pacific nation's coast.

items.title: Australian people smuggling operation laid bare in NT Supreme Court
items.summary: A brazen example of people smuggling has been recounted in the Northern Territory Supreme Court, after three Chinese nationals made it into Darwin Harbour on a small wooden fishing boat.

items.title: Adelaide public transport, stations and interchanges join list of declared public precincts
items.summary: Police have been given expanded powers to search people for weapons on every public bus, train and tram in the Adelaide metropolitan area ahead of New Year Eve's celebrations.
